papers.abstract: Technologies are increasingly enrolled in projects to involve civilians in the work of policy-making, often under the label of 'civic technology'. But conventional forms of participation through transactions such as voting provide limited opportunities for engagement. In response, some civic tech groups organize around issues of shared concern to explore new forms of democratic technologies. How does their work affect the relationship between publics and public servants? This paper explores how a Civic Tech Toronto creates a platform for civic engagement through the maintenance of an autonomous community for civic engagement and participation that is casual, social, nonpartisan, experimental, and flexible. Based on two years of action research, including community organizing, interviews, and observations, this paper shows how this grassroots civic tech group creates a civic platform that places a diverse range of participants in contact with the work of public servants, helping to build capacities and relationships that prepare both publics and public servants for the work of participatory democracy. The case shows that understanding civic tech requires a lens beyond the mere analysis or production of technical artifacts. As a practice for making technologies that is social and participatory, civic tech creates alternative modes of technology development and opportunities for experimentation and learning, and it can reconfigure the roles of democratic participants.

Based on two years of action research, including community organizing, interviews, and observations, this paper shows how this grassroots civic tech group creates a civic platform that places a diverse range of participants in contact with the work of public servants, helping to build capacities and relationships that prepare both publics and public servants for the work of participatory democracy.

events.Text: The case shows that understanding civic tech requires a lens beyond the mere analysis or production of technical artifacts. As a practice for making technologies that is social and participatory, civic tech creates alternative modes of technology development and opportunities for experimentation and learning, and it can reconfigure the roles of democratic participants.

Context: traditional view of technology as merely technical artifacts
Purpose: challenging conventional views and providing new perspectives
Method: examining practices instead of focusing solely on artifacts
Results: emergence of alternative development methods and reconfigured roles
Analysis: interpretation of these findings for democracy and design
Challenge: difficulty in measuring impacts and ensuring equity
Ethical: considerations of power dynamics and inclusivity
Implications: broader societal impact and future research directions
Contradictions: disparities between established views and new perspectives

papers.abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) based technologies are increasingly being integrated into public sector programs to help with decision-support and effective distribution of constrained resources. The field of Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW) has begun to examine how the resultant sociotechnical systems may be designed appropriately when targeting underserved populations. We present an ethnographic study of a large-scale real-world integration of an AI system for resource allocation in a call-based maternal and child health program in India. Our findings uncover complexities around determining who benefits from the intervention, how the human-AI collaboration is managed, when intervention must take place in alignment with various priorities, and why the AI is sought, for what purpose. Our paper offers takeaways for human-centered AI integration in public health, drawing attention to the work done by the AI as actor, the work of configuring the human-AI partnership with multiple diverse stakeholders, and the work of aligning program goals for design and implementation through continual dialogue across stakeholders.

events.Text: Artificial Intelligence (AI) based technologies are increasingly being integrated into public sector programs to help with decision-support and effective distribution of constrained resources. The field of Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW) has begun to examine how the resultant sociotechnical systems may be designed appropriately when targeting underserved populations.
We present an ethnographic study of a large-scale real-world integration of an AI system for resource allocation in a call-based maternal and child health program in India.

Secondary Object: a large-scale real-world integration of an AI system

Context: a call-based maternal and child health program in India

events.Text: Our findings uncover complexities around determining who benefits from the intervention, how the human-AI collaboration is managed, when intervention must take place in alignment with various priorities, and why the AI is sought, for what purpose.
events.Main Action: Their findings uncover complexities around determining who benefits from the intervention, how the human-AI collaboration is managed, when intervention must take place in alignment with various priorities, and why the AI is sought, for what purpose.

Primary Object: Complexities around determining who benefits from the intervention, how the human-AI collaboration is managed, when intervention must take place in alignment with various priorities, and why the AI is sought, for what purpose.

Context: Understanding the nature of human-AI collaboration, the optimal timing of intervention relative to various priorities, and the motivations driving the utilization of AI systems.
Purpose: Exploring factors influencing beneficiary identification, effective management strategies within human-AI partnerships, synchronization of intervention timelines with organizational goals, and underlying motives prompting AI deployment.
Results: Findings reveal multifaceted challenges impacting the effectiveness of AI integration across diverse scenarios.
Implications: These insights offer valuable guidance for optimizing AI-driven initiatives and enhancing collaborative efforts between humans and AI systems in various domains.

events.Text: Our paper offers takeaways for human-centered AI integration in public health, drawing attention to the work done by the AI as actor, the work of configuring the human-AI partnership with multiple diverse stakeholders, and the work of aligning program goals for design and implementation through continual dialogue across stakeholders.

Purpose: Addressing challenges and providing insights into integrating AI in public health
Results: Configuring the human-AI partnership with multiple diverse stakeholders and aligning program goals for design and implementation through continual dialogue across stakeholders
Analysis: Interpreting the findings regarding the role of AI in public health
Implications: Influencing policy and practice in public health through human-centered AI
